choices.text: Dorsal root ganglion in Spinal cord

questions.text: In this image following type of neuron is seen in
questions.solution:
• Unipolar: Having only one pole
    • Present in embryonic stage (all developing neurons) in human being
    • Eg. Mesencephalic nucleus of 5th cranial nerve
  • Bipolar: Having two poles
    • Axon arises one pole and dendrites other pole
    • Eg. In retina, vestibular ganglion, olfactory epithelium, cochlea
  • Pseudo unipolar: From single pole both axon and dendrites arise
    • These types of neurons are first typically bipolar but they converge to meet on one side of cell body and elongates to form T shaped process
    • Eg. In spinal ganglia and ganglia of all cranial nerves except 8th cranial nerve
  • Multipolar: Nucleus having multipoles
    • Axon arise one pole & all other pole give rise dendrites
    • Eg. Motor neurons in spinal cord, Pyramidal cells, Purkinje cells in cerebellum.

Tag: Neuronal classification

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number:216,218 fig 4-2

questions.text: Identify the factor marked with question mark?
questions.solution:
• Enterokinase is an enzyme secreted from the cells of small intestine it causes activation of trypsinogen to trypsin. Trypsin is a protein digesting enzyme.
  • The making with - is a trypsin which further causes activation of
    • Trypsinogen to trypsin
    • Chymotrypsinogen to trypsin
    • Procarboxypeptidase to carboxypeptidase
  • Aminopeptidase is an enzyme that causes breakdown of polypeptide into aminoacids.
  • At PH of around 7 or more all above enzymes remains active for digestion in the small intestine.

Tag: Digestion and absorption

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 1102 fig 26-3

questions.text: Identify the following property of nerve muscle diagram.
questions.solution:
• In the diagram at one voltage potential, the channel may remain closed all the time or almost all the time, whereas at another voltage, it may remain open either all or most of the time. The diagram depicts all or none law.
  • Refractory period refers to the time period following an action potential during which a neuron or muscle fiber is less responsive or unresponsive to additional stimuli. It is different in different excitable tissues.
  • Impulse conduction depends on
    • Myelination - saltatory conduction
    • Unmyelinated - continuous conduction
  • In the graded potential as the strength of stimulus increases the response increases. It does not fit with the diagram. It is not the correct option.

Tag: Properties

Reference: Guyton and Hall textbook of Medical physiology 14th Edition, Chapter 4,fig 4-6 page number. 55, 74, 76

questions.text: Identify that following normal ECG is taken from lead
questions.solution:
• Depolarization moving toward an active electrode produces a positive deflection, whereas depolarization moving in the opposite direction produces a negative deflection.
  • Unipolar limb leads measure the potential differences between exploring electrode (attached positive terminal of the electrocardiograph) and indifferent electrode.
    • aVR is the potential difference between RA (positive electrode) & (LA + LL).
    • aVL is the potential difference between LA ((positive electrode) & (RA + LL).
  • In Lead I negative terminal of the electrocardiograph is connected to the right arm and positive terminal to the left arm.
  • Lead V4- exploring (positive terminal) electrode in midclavicular line in the fifth left intercostal space.
  • If we observe above leads in aVR the summed up current flows opposite to the exploring electrode producing negative deflection in QRS complex.
  • In the remaining leads the summedup current flows in the direction fo exploring electrode producing positive QRS complex

Tag: ECG

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Edition Chapter:11 Page number.140

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient has injury in lateral white column of spinal cord on the right side at C4 segment of spinal cord. Patient lost the sensation of fine touch, pressure, vibration, proprioception. The limb probably affected in this case is
questions.solution:
• Dorsal column medial leminiscus pathway carries following sensations
    • Fine touch,
    • Tactile localization and discrimination
    • Vibration and pressure
    • Proprioception
    • Kinesthetic sensation
    • Stereognosis
  • The spatial orientation of fibers in the spinal cord from medial to lateral is sacral, lumbar, thoracic, cervical.
  • As shown in the figure the lateral fibers are cut probably the thoracic and cervical fibers are damaged on the right side of the spinal cord.
  • The right side of the spinal cord carries DCML tract sensation of the right side as this tract crosses in the brain stem. It carries same side fibres.
  • So right spinal cord thoracic and cervical fibers are damaged that leads to loss of DCML tract sensation of right side.
  • Upper limb fibers are supplied by C5 to T1 segments of the spinal cord. Upper limb fibers are likely to be damaged.

Tag: Sensory tracts

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Edition, page number:609 fig 48-13

questions.text: Estimate the FEV1/FVC ratio from the graph showing dynamic spirometry and select the correct option.
questions.solution:
• Forced vital capacity (FVC)-It is the volume of air in liters that can be forcefully and maximally exhaled after a maximal inspiration
  • From the graph we can depict the forced vital capacity is 7-2 =5 liters approximately.
  • Forced expiratory volume 1 is 7- 2.8 = 4.2 liters that is the amount of air that comes out from the lung in 1st
  • The ratio of FEV1/FVC is 4.2/5 = 0.84 %

Tag: Spirometry

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 1436

questions.text: Identify the type of heat transfer marked with an arrow.
questions.solution:
• Above mentioned processes by which heat is lost from the body when the environmental temperature is below body temperature.
  • Exchange of heat between objects at different temperatures that are in contact with one another is known as conduction, as shown in the figure marked with an arrow.
  • The movement of air in the surrounding area loses heat by mechanism of convection, as shown in the last figure.
  • Transfer of heat from one object to another at a different temperature with which it is not in contact is It is shown in the second figure.
  • Perspiration (Evaporation) is a heat loss mechanism by sweat secretion.
  • We can remember these mechanisms as C-CPR

Tag: Body temperature

References: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Edition, page number. 903

questions.text: Identify the normal osmolarity of fluid marked with an arrow.
questions.solution:
• The fluid marked with an arrow is interstitial fluid. The fluid red in color is plasma. These two together form extracellular fluid. The fluid inside the cells is intracellular fluid.
  • All these fluids have nearly similar osmolarity.
  • Normal plasma osmolarity is nearly 290 mosm/kg.
    Approx 270 mosm/kg by Na+, Cl-, HCO3-, remaining 20 mosm/kg by glucose and urea, approx 2 mosm/kg by plasma proteins due to lesser no. of particles.
  • In the interstitial fluid there is no plasma proteins, but it contributes to very less osmolarity.
  • So plasma, interstitial fluid and intracellular fluid osmolality is same that is nearly 290 mosm/kg.

Tag: Plasma proteins

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 34

questions.text: Identify the protein marked with an arrow in the figure that helps in calcium absorption from intestine
questions.solution:
• Calbindin- It is calcium binding protein. It binds with calcium ion in the intestinal epithelial cell, so that it does not disturb epithelial signaling processes that involve calcium.
  • PMCA1b- plasma membrane calcium ATPase. It helps the calcium to enter in the blood stream from the basolateral surface via active transport mechanism.
  • NCX1- Na+/Ca+ exchanger- It is found on the basolateral membrane of the intestinal epithelial cells. Here it exchanges Na+ and calcium in opposite direction.
  • TRPV6- transient receptor potential vanilloid type 6- Ca2+ is taken up into the body across the brush border of intestinal epithelial cells via TRPV6 channels.
  • Calbindin- It is calcium binding protein. It binds with calcium ion in the intestinal epithelial cell, so that it does not disturb epithelial signaling processes that involve calcium.

Tag: Calcium homeostasis

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 863 fig 21-2

questions.text: Identify the event in the cardiac cycle marked with an arrow.
questions.solution:
• Above diagram is of normal pressure volume loop of left ventricle.
  • Features of the phase marked with arrow
    • Position of valves
      Atrioventricular valve - close
      Semilunar valve - close
    • Pressure
      Form nearly 0 to 80 mmHg
  • As the features suggest it is isometric contraction phase (Phase II) in the Cardiac cycle.
  • Opening of the aortic valve marks the end of isometric contraction phase and starts the ejection phase (Phase III). The volume of ventricle reduces from 150 ml to 50 ml.
  • After that pressure suddenly falls after the aortic valve closes marks the isometric relaxation phase (Phase IV) of cardiac cycle. The pressure falls from around 100 to nearly 0 mmHg. The volume remains same.
  • The phase I at the bottom is filling phase in the ventricle where the volume rises from 50 to 150 ml nearly.

Tag: Cardiac Cycle

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 1222 fig. 30-2

questions.text: See the following image and recognize it is a graph of
questions.solution:
• In above image resting membrane potential is -50 mv.
  • There is prolonged repolarization with plateau phase in the image.

Reference: Guyton and Hall textbook of Medical physiology 14th Edition, page number:107 fig 8-7

questions.text: Following is a pulse pressure contour. It is seen in which of the following vessel in normal healthy adult?
questions.solution:
• The pulse pressure contour is a graphical representation of how this pressure changes throughout the vascular system.
    As blood moves from the heart through the arteries, arterioles, and capillaries, the contour of the pulse pressure changes due to factors such as vessel elasticity, resistance, and distance from the heart.
  • Option a: The aorta has a characteristic pulse pressure contour with a sharp, rapid upstroke (reflecting the systolic ejection from the left ventricle) and a gradual downstroke.
    The contour shows a small dicrotic notch, which represents the closure of the aortic valve.
  • Option b: In the femoral artery, the pulse pressure is generally higher than in the aorta, with a sharper, more peaked upstroke and a steeper downstroke.
  • Option c: In arterioles, the pulse pressure is significantly dampened. The contour is less distinct, with a smaller difference between systolic and diastolic pressures.
  • Option d: In capillaries, there is virtually no pulse pressure; the pressure is steady and non-pulsatile.

Reference: Guyton and Hall textbook of Medical physiology 14th Edition, page number:186 fig 15-6

questions.text: Following is a field of visual field defect. The lesion marked with no. 3 produces which of the following defect?
questions.solution:
• Option a: A visual field defect in which there is loss of vision in the nasal (medial) half of the visual field in one eye.
    • It is typically caused by damage to the lateral part of the optic chiasm, where the fibers from the nasal (medial) half of the retina (which corresponds to the temporal visual field) cross over to the opposite side.
  • Option b: A loss of vision in the same half of the visual field in both eyes (either both right halves or both left halves).
    • It results from damage to the optic tract, optic radiation, or the occipital cortex on one side of the brain after the optic chiasm
  • Option c: A visual field defect characterized by the loss of vision in the temporal (lateral) half of the visual field in both eyes.
    • Damage to the central part of the optic chiasm, where the nasal fibers from each eye cross over produces this type of defect.
  • Option d: loss of vision or blindness in one or both eyes.
    • It can result from the damage to the optic nerve.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 469 fig. 10-14

questions.text: Identify the following disorder.
questions.solution:
Clinical features of Cushing’s syndrome (Cause: increase in glucocorticoid)

  • Truncal or centripetal obesity
  • Moon face, Buffalo hump
  • Purple striae or cutaneous abdominal striae
  • Muscle weakness & backache
  • Thin limbs
  • Osteoporosis & bone fracture
  • Susceptibility to infection & Impaired wound healing
  • Diabetes
  • Sodium & water retention may cause oedema, hypertension
  • Acne, hirsutism
  • Blackening of skin due to pigmentation
  • Susceptibility to peptic ulceration

Features of hypothyroidism (decrease in thyroid hormone)

  • Non pitting type of edema.
  • Bagginess under eyes
  • swelling of face.

Conn’s syndrome occurs due to increase in aldosterone secretion.

Dwarfism (less height compared to others of same age) can occur due to nutritional deficiency, decrease in growth hormone, of GH receptor defect, hypothyroid child.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number.802

questions.text: Following image shows antigen present on the RBC membrane. Identify the one marked with an arrow. This antigen is found in which of the following blood group.
questions.solution:
• According to ABO blood group system there are four blood groups A, B, AB, O.
  • The H antigen is a fundamental carbohydrate structure found on the surface of red blood cells and is the precursor to the ABO blood group antigens.
    • H antigen is present in all of the above blood groups. An H gene codes for a fucose transferase that adds a terminal fucose, forming the H antigen.
  • In individuals with blood type O, the H antigen remains unmodified, as they lack the enzymes (glycosyltransferases) necessary to convert the H antigen into A or B antigens.
  • Individuals who are type B express a transferase that places a terminal galactose.
  • Individuals who are type A also express a second transferase that catalyzes placement of a terminal N-acetylgalactosamine on the H antigen.
  • In AB blood group type both transferase are found.
  • In rare cases, individuals lack the gene responsible for the production of the H antigen (FUT1 gene mutation). These individuals have a blood type known as the Bombay phenotype.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 1275 fig 31-9
